data.title: Decode the prime-ary numbers
data.solution:
require 'prime'
n = gets.chomp
s = n.size
Primes = Prime.take(s)
digits = n.chars.reverse
values = digits.map.with_index{|c,i| Primes[i.to_i]**c.to_i }
product = values.reduce(:*)
puts product
data.statement:
You have devised a system of representing numbers similar to binary, but instead of {{<<100>>}} meaning {{1*<<4>>+0*<<2>>+0*<<1>>}} (as in binary), it now means {{<<5>>^1*<<3>>^0*<<2>>^0}} which you call {{prime-ary}}.

An n-digit {{prime-ary}} number has each digit represent how many times each prime number divides the number evenly, starting with the first prime, 2, from the right and extending leftwards. It is about multiplication of primes rather than addition of powers of 2 (as in binary)

<<How to read prime-ary:>>
```
<<201>>
||└ 2^<<1>>*
|└─ 3^<<0>>*
└─── 5^<<2>> = 25*1*2 = 50 (in decimal)
```

The prime numbers are 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, ... and every positive integer can be represented as a unique number of this form, although some numbers would need more digits than 0-9. Here we stick to just 0-9.

Now write some code to read a number in {{prime-ary}} and print it in decimal!
data.constraints:
No digits in the prime-ary number will exceed 9
No primes above 300 will be involved in any calculations. Longest input will be 60 digits.
1 < [[n]] < 10^10
data.stubGenerator:
read prim:string(70)
write 50

INPUT
prim: The number in prime-ary

OUTPUT
The number in decimal

STATEMENT
Prime-ary numbers. '200' => 5^2 * 3^0 * 2^0 = 25
data.inputDescription: <<1 Line>>: A string [[prim]] representing a number in prime-ary
data.outputDescription: <<1 Line>>: The number [[n]] in decimal that is represented by the input [[prim]]

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You have devised a system of representing numbers similar to binary, but instead of 100 meaning 1*4+0*2+0*1 (as in binary), it now means 5^1*3^0*2^0 which you call prime-ary.

An n-digit prime-ary number has each digit represent how many times each prime number divides the number evenly, starting with the first prime, 2, from the right and extending leftwards. It is about multiplication of primes rather than addition of powers of 2 (as in binary)

How to read prime-ary:

201
||└ 2^1*
|└─ 3^0*
└─── 5^2 = 25*1*2 = 50 (in decimal)


The prime numbers are 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, ... and every positive integer can be represented as a unique number of this form, although some numbers would need more digits than 0-9. Here we stick to just 0-9.

Now write some code to read a number in prime-ary and print it in decimal!




   

      
Input

      
1 Line: A string prim representing a number in prime-ary

   

   

      
Output

      
1 Line: The number n in decimal that is represented by the input prim

   

   

      
Constraints

      
No digits in the prime-ary number will exceed 9
No primes above 300 will be involved in any calculations. Longest input will be 60 digits.
1 < n < 10^10

   

   

      
Example

      

         

            
Input

            
201

         

         

            
Output

            
50
